Articles.Content: There were plans to strap another Zenit lower stage to a Zenit rocket, but attached sideways like a booster. What if you did this with a Falcon 9?

The Zenit is powered by an RD-171 developed from the RD-170 which had enough gimbal to launch a rocket upside-down (something like 10°): it was built for Energia which is basically a (better) Space Shuttle with the SSMEs on the ET, so the whole thing had to launch sideways. Though the engines developed from the RD-170 (RD-171 and RD-180) have had their gimbals reduced a bit, it's still pretty big and allows for slightly asymmetrical launches (see the Atlas V family with its SRBs all over the place).

I expect that an asymmetric Zenit would be powered by an updated RD-171 with a bit of additional gimbal to help stabilise it.

The Merlin was never developed for asymmetrical configurations and I doubt it would work correctly.

 

Long story short: your Falcon 9 Semi-Heavy will do a nice flip and that's pretty much it.

 

Edit: BTW, if anyone found a source with the gimbal range of the Merlin engine, I'd be interested to see it, I couldn't find any.

Edited January 5, 2017 by Gaarst

4 hours ago, Gaarst said:

The Zenit is powered by an RD-171 developed from the RD-170 which had enough gimbal to launch a rocket upside-down (something like 10°): it was built for Energia which is basically a (better) Space Shuttle with the SSMEs on the ET, so the whole thing had to launch sideways. I expect that an asymmetric Zenit would be powered by an updated RD-171 with a bit of additional gimbal to help stabilise it.

Long story short: your Falcon 9 Semi-Heavy will do a nice flip and that's pretty much it.

 

Edit: BTW, if anyone found a source with the gimbal range of the Merlin engine, I'd be interested to see it, I couldn't find any.

I used SSTU Merlins on a test one in KSP and it flew fine...

22 hours ago, _Augustus_ said:

I used SSTU Merlins on a test one in KSP and it flew fine...

Yeah, but that isn't really evidence for IRL.

Now, if they balanced the thrust to counteract the torque(assuming the Merlin can throttle) and lower the propellant load in the core, it's a slim possibility. The CG would move away from the core, the issue being that the thrust from the booster would apply torque. Maybe, if you could put an upperstage on the booster... But that would be really expensive and very time consuming just for R&D.
